articles.description: U.S. Sen. Kamala Harris Friday toured the Otay Mesa Immigration and Detention Facility, where she visited migrant mothers who were separated from their children in what the California Democrat called "a crime against humanity being committed by the U.S. gover…

articles.author: Kate Morrissey
articles.title: Migrants from Central American caravan face a long road to asylum in U.S.
articles.description: A caravan of asylum seekers from Central America made it to the California border Sunday. Here’s a look at what’s ahead for them: What do we know about this caravan? At its largest, the caravan reportedly numbered about 1,200 people, mostly from Central Ameri…

articles.author: Kate Morrissey
articles.title: Operator moves to expand detention center for migrants in San Diego County
articles.description: A contractor working for private prison company CoreCivic has applied for construction permits to expand Otay Mesa Detention Center in southern San Diego County, which houses immigrants awaiting court proceedings. The plans would add 512 beds to the facility …

articles.author: Elise Schmelzer elise.schmelzer@trib.com
articles.title: Private prison company pursuing Wyoming immigration detention center has troubled past
articles.description: Leaders in southwest Wyoming appear willing to overlook the troubled history of a private prison company attempting to build an immigration detention facility outside Evanston in order to bring what they say the community needs most — jobs and revenue.

articles.author: Gustavo Solis and David Hernandez
articles.title: About a third of caravan migrants enter U.S., but 'we won’t be happy until the last one of us gets through'
articles.description: Spirits were high Wednesday as more members of the Central American caravan — about one-third of the roughly 150 who made the trek — entered the United States. But as their monthlong journey to the United States comes to an end, those seeking asylum are prepa…

articles.author: Meredith Hoffman
articles.title: Trump Sent Judges to the Border. Many Had Nothing to Do.
articles.description: The administration's plan to speed up deportations and reduce the immigration court backlog might be making things worse.
